wrote:

I remember right as I hit enter. I used zpool iostat -v 1

wrote:

> I'm curious if there is a way to test if the SLOG is working. I remember
> doing this quite awhile ago on another box, but I can't remember the

I remember right as I hit enter. I used zpool iostat -v 1
item.dc:creator: greg@leiengineering.com

item.title: Pkgin with retry
item.description:
I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.

The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
firewall of China in action.

Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
wget --tries=100 --continue
to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
do the equivalent?

-Tim

--
http://timboudreau.com
I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.

The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
firewall of China in action.

Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
wget --tries=100 --continue
to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
do the equivalent?

-Tim

--
http://timboudreau.com
item.dc:creator: niftiness@gmail.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss wrote:
> On Tue, Jan 20, 2015 at 11:05 PM, Greg Zartman
> <greg@leiengineering.com <mailto:greg@leiengineering.com>>; wrote:
>
> I'm curious if there is a way to test if the SLOG is working. I
> remember doing this quite awhile ago on another box, but I can't
> remember the command.
>
>
> I remember right as I hit enter. I used zpool iostat -v 1
>
iostat -xtcMn 30 (or more)

gives you a better idea.

--
Ian.

> On Tue, Jan 20, 2015 at 11:05 PM, Greg Zartman
> <greg@leiengineering.com <mailto:greg@leiengineering.com>>; wrote:
>
> I'm curious if there is a way to test if the SLOG is working. I
> remember doing this quite awhile ago on another box, but I can't
> remember the command.
>
>
> I remember right as I hit enter. I used zpool iostat -v 1
>
iostat -xtcMn 30 (or more)

gives you a better idea.

--
Ian.

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Pkgin with retry
item.description:
On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 02:30:37AM -0500, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss wrote:
> I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
> SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.
>
> The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
> firewall of China in action.
>
> Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
> wget --tries=100 --continue
> to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
> do the equivalent?
>
> -Tim
>
> --
> http://timboudreau.com

This is a bit of an X/Y problem - I wouldn't trust anything downloaded over
that connection in the first place. You're basically giving the PRC root
access to your VMs if they can modify data in transit.

Jon
On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 02:30:37AM -0500, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss wrote:
> I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
> SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.
>
> The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
> firewall of China in action.
>
> Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
> wget --tries=100 --continue
> to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
> do the equivalent?
>
> -Tim
>
> --
> http://timboudreau.com

This is a bit of an X/Y problem - I wouldn't trust anything downloaded over
that connection in the first place. You're basically giving the PRC root
access to your VMs if they can modify data in transit.

Jon
item.dc:creator: jon@dorsal.tk

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Pkgin with retry
item.description:
* On 2015-01-21 at 08:00 GMT, Jonathan Lane via smartos-discuss wrote:

> On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 02:30:37AM -0500, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss wrote:
>
> > I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
> > SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.
> >
> > The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
> > firewall of China in action.
> >
> > Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
> > wget --tries=100 --continue
> > to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
> > do the equivalent?
>
> This is a bit of an X/Y problem - I wouldn't trust anything downloaded over
> that connection in the first place. You're basically giving the PRC root
> access to your VMs if they can modify data in transit.

While not outside the realms of possibility, this would be difficult
with our packages, as there are various checksums and size checks in
both the package itself and the pkgin database that would mean a MITM
would need to modify the data in a multitude of places and with
consistency across multiple downloads.

The missing piece in the puzzle is signed packages, and this is
something I want to implement quite soon - stay tuned for that.

As for the original question, there's no way I know of to retry
downloads, however you can simply use wget/curl to download the
packages individually then use pkg_add(1) to install them from the
local file system. The only difficulty here is that you need to
handle dependencies yourself.

If you had the disk space, the best solution would be to simply mirror
the pkgsrc servers somewhere in China. We offer public rsync on them
to make this easy, and other SmartOS users in China would I'm sure be
very grateful to you ;)

--
Jonathan Perkin - Joyent, Inc. - www.joyent.com
* On 2015-01-21 at 08:00 GMT, Jonathan Lane via smartos-discuss wrote:

> On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 02:30:37AM -0500, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss wrote:
>
> > I'm installing a bunch of packages on a machine in Fenquiyun's Beijing
> > SmartOS cloud, which downloads from Joyent's package servers.
> >
> > The result is that large packages frequently fail to download - the great
> > firewall of China in action.
> >
> > Is there any way to convince pkgin to download ala
> > wget --tries=100 --continue
> > to keep trying until the download is complete? Or a set of manual steps to
> > do the equivalent?
>
> This is a bit of an X/Y problem - I wouldn't trust anything downloaded over
> that connection in the first place. You're basically giving the PRC root
> access to your VMs if they can modify data in transit.

While not outside the realms of possibility, this would be difficult
with our packages, as there are various checksums and size checks in
both the package itself and the pkgin database that would mean a MITM
would need to modify the data in a multitude of places and with
consistency across multiple downloads.

The missing piece in the puzzle is signed packages, and this is
something I want to implement quite soon - stay tuned for that.

As for the original question, there's no way I know of to retry
downloads, however you can simply use wget/curl to download the
packages individually then use pkg_add(1) to install them from the
local file system. The only difficulty here is that you need to
handle dependencies yourself.

If you had the disk space, the best solution would be to simply mirror
the pkgsrc servers somewhere in China. We offer public rsync on them
to make this easy, and other SmartOS users in China would I'm sure be
very grateful to you ;)

--
Jonathan Perkin - Joyent, Inc. - www.joyent.com
item.dc:creator: jperkin@joyent.com

item.title: MongoDB Image VS Generic
item.description:
Hello.

I had a quick question relating to SmartOS images.

What's the difference between using a MongoDB image vs using a generic
SmartOS image ind installing MongoDB using pkgin?

I guess this also relates to other application specific images.

TIA.

Sam
Hello.

I had a quick question relating to SmartOS images.

What's the difference between using a MongoDB image vs using a generic
SmartOS image ind installing MongoDB using pkgin?

I guess this also relates to other application specific images.

TIA.

Sam
item.dc:creator: emunch@utmi.in

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] MongoDB Image VS Generic
item.description:
Hi Sam

Best bet is to look here:

https://docs.joyent.com/images/smartos/mongodb

which details all the specifics about the MongoDB instances. Its some tuning and all the pre-reqs installed.

Sam

item.title: SDC question
item.description:
Hi

We are looking at SDC again after last seeing it as version 6.x - so far
looking good.

I was wondering if the customer portal is part of the open source release ?
For a private cloud deployment at a customer would they use the operator
portal ?

Thanks
Len
Hi

We are looking at SDC again after last seeing it as version 6.x - so far
looking good.

I was wondering if the customer portal is part of the open source release ?
For a private cloud deployment at a customer would they use the operator
portal ?

Thanks
Len
item.dc:creator: len@cloudafrica.net

item.title: Moving from USB to PXE
item.description:
Probably a simple question - I'd just like to understand the process better
before I try it.

I have 3 SmartOS hosts running in one subnet. They currently boot from
individual USB sticks. I''m interested in moving them to PXE to make new
SmartOS releases simpler to implement.

Currently there is no DHCP server in that network because none is needed.
There are only a few servers and each server has a static IP.

Is the network that the PXE boot method uses to boot and load the OS into
memory typically the same network as will be used to manage the server?

In other words, if my current servers are 192.168.1.100, 101 and 102, and I
want to keep those addresses, do I need to change each host to PXE boot
from DHCP and use reservations to make sure that each server still gets its
original IP address? Or is the PXE boot network independent of the
management network and the server just boots from NIC #1 on some other IP
but is managed on NIC #2 connected to the "management" network?

Hopefully I'm explaining my question well enough. Thanks!

--
Mark
Probably a simple question - I'd just like to understand the process better
before I try it.

I have 3 SmartOS hosts running in one subnet. They currently boot from
individual USB sticks. I''m interested in moving them to PXE to make new
SmartOS releases simpler to implement.

Currently there is no DHCP server in that network because none is needed.
There are only a few servers and each server has a static IP.

Is the network that the PXE boot method uses to boot and load the OS into
memory typically the same network as will be used to manage the server?

In other words, if my current servers are 192.168.1.100, 101 and 102, and I
want to keep those addresses, do I need to change each host to PXE boot
from DHCP and use reservations to make sure that each server still gets its
original IP address? Or is the PXE boot network independent of the
management network and the server just boots from NIC #1 on some other IP
but is managed on NIC #2 connected to the "management" network?

Hopefully I'm explaining my question well enough. Thanks!

--
Mark
item.dc:creator: whitetr6@gmail.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
OK, I purchased and intel 3700 and put it in the pool as follows:

zpool add zones log c0t55CD2E404B716B8Ed0

Didnt' format the drive, partition it or anythign else.

I went to the VM that uses the NFS mounts and I'm not seeing any difference:

Before:

[root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
count=1024; sync
1024+0 records in
1024+0 records out
1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.8062 s, 90.9 MB/s


After:
[root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
count=1024; sync
1024+0 records in
1024+0 records out
1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.4983 s, 93.4 MB/s


Am I missing something?


Greg J. Zartman, P.E.
President, Principal Engineer

LEI Engineering & Surveying, LLC
2160 Davcor Street SE
Salem, Oregon 97302
Office: 541-683-8383 (ext 103) Cell: 541-521-8449 Fax: 866-232-6790
www.leiengineering.com

SBA Certified HUBZone Contractor

On Mon, Jan 19, 2015 at 12:15 AM, Greg Zartman <greg@leiengineering.com>
wrote:

>
> On Sun, Jan 18, 2015 at 11:25 PM, Peter Toth <peter.toth198@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Just for reference:
>>
>> I have tested an Intel DC 3500 SSD as an slog device today - from a
>> CentOS KVM guest doing dd with 64k block size.
>>
>> Average write speed 270MB/s - I think that speaks for itself.
>>
> Wow, yea that sounds more like it. Couple questions:
>
> 1. Did you do a write big enough to make sure you weren't just writing
> RAM?
>
> 2. What's you zpool config and what kind of hardware you running? That
> is, what kind of vdevs do you have?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Greg
>
OK, I purchased and intel 3700 and put it in the pool as follows:

zpool add zones log c0t55CD2E404B716B8Ed0

Didnt' format the drive, partition it or anythign else.

I went to the VM that uses the NFS mounts and I'm not seeing any difference:

Before:

[root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
count=1024; sync
1024+0 records in
1024+0 records out
1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.8062 s, 90.9 MB/s


After:
[root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
count=1024; sync
1024+0 records in
1024+0 records out
1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.4983 s, 93.4 MB/s


Am I missing something?


Greg J. Zartman, P.E.
President, Principal Engineer

LEI Engineering & Surveying, LLC
2160 Davcor Street SE
Salem, Oregon 97302
Office: 541-683-8383 (ext 103) Cell: 541-521-8449 Fax: 866-232-6790
www.leiengineering.com

SBA Certified HUBZone Contractor

wrote:

>
> On Sun, Jan 18, 2015 at 11:25 PM, Peter Toth <peter.toth198@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Just for reference:
>>
>> I have tested an Intel DC 3500 SSD as an slog device today - from a
>> CentOS KVM guest doing dd with 64k block size.
>>
>> Average write speed 270MB/s - I think that speaks for itself.
>>
> Wow, yea that sounds more like it. Couple questions:
>
> 1. Did you do a write big enough to make sure you weren't just writing
> RAM?
>
> 2. What's you zpool config and what kind of hardware you running? That

>
> Thanks,
>
> Greg

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
On 1/21/15 11:15 , Greg Zartman wrote:
> OK, I purchased and intel 3700 and put it in the pool as follows:
>
> zpool add zones log c0t55CD2E404B716B8Ed0
>
> Didnt' format the drive, partition it or anythign else.
>
> I went to the VM that uses the NFS mounts and I'm not seeing any difference:
>
> Before:
>
> [root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
> count=1024; sync
> 1024+0 records in
> 1024+0 records out
> 1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.8062 s, 90.9 MB/s
>
>
> After:
> [root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
> count=1024; sync
> 1024+0 records in
> 1024+0 records out
> 1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.4983 s, 93.4 MB/s
>
>
> Am I missing something?

Did you actually characterize where you're spending your time? Are you
sure that right now all your latency is due to disk I/O?
On 1/21/15 11:15 , Greg Zartman wrote:
> OK, I purchased and intel 3700 and put it in the pool as follows:
>
> zpool add zones log c0t55CD2E404B716B8Ed0
>
> Didnt' format the drive, partition it or anythign else.
>
> I went to the VM that uses the NFS mounts and I'm not seeing any difference:
>
> Before:
>
> [root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
> count=1024; sync
> 1024+0 records in
> 1024+0 records out
> 1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.8062 s, 90.9 MB/s
>
>
> After:
> [root@nameserver files]# sync; dd if=/dev/zero of=tempfile bs=1M
> count=1024; sync
> 1024+0 records in
> 1024+0 records out
> 1073741824 bytes (1.1 GB) copied, 11.4983 s, 93.4 MB/s
>
>
> Am I missing something?

Did you actually characterize where you're spending your time? Are you
sure that right now all your latency is due to disk I/O?
item.dc:creator: rm@joyent.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Moving from USB to PXE
item.description:
Hi,

From experience, DHCP could give out generic ip addresses for the PXE
client, then if your zpool is setup and you have /usbkey/config your
smartos host will use the information in there.

Seb,

On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 2:06 PM, Mark Creamer via smartos-discuss <
smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:

> Probably a simple question - I'd just like to understand the process
> better before I try it.
>
> I have 3 SmartOS hosts running in one subnet. They currently boot from
> individual USB sticks. I''m interested in moving them to PXE to make new
> SmartOS releases simpler to implement.
>
> Currently there is no DHCP server in that network because none is needed.
> There are only a few servers and each server has a static IP.
>
> Is the network that the PXE boot method uses to boot and load the OS into
> memory typically the same network as will be used to manage the server?
>
> In other words, if my current servers are 192.168.1.100, 101 and 102, and
> I want to keep those addresses, do I need to change each host to PXE boot
> from DHCP and use reservations to make sure that each server still gets its
> original IP address? Or is the PXE boot network independent of the
> management network and the server just boots from NIC #1 on some other IP
> but is managed on NIC #2 connected to the "management" network?
>
> Hopefully I'm explaining my question well enough. Thanks!
>
> --
> Mark

> <https://www.listbox.com/member/archive/184463/=now>;
> <https://www.listbox.com/member/archive/rss/184463/26900931-98fbc364>; |

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Moving from USB to PXE
item.description:
There is no reason why you can't setup a DHCP static lease for your SmartOS
server.

On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Sebastien Perreault via smartos-discuss <
smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:

> Hi,
>
> From experience, DHCP could give out generic ip addresses for the PXE

> E: sperreault@alesium.net
>
> "Life's missed opportunities, at the end, may seem more poignant to us
> than those we embraced--because in our imagination they have a perfection
> that reality can never rival." -- Roger Ebert
> *smartos-discuss* | Archives
> <https://www.listbox.com/member/archive/184463/=now>;

--
Greg

http://www.linkedin.com/in/gregtreantos
There is no reason why you can't setup a DHCP static lease for your SmartOS
server.

On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 2:49 PM, Sebastien Perreault via smartos-discuss <
smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:

> Hi,
>
> From experience, DHCP could give out generic ip addresses for the PXE
> client, then if your zpool is setup and you have /usbkey/config your
> smartos host will use the information in there.
>
> Seb,
>
> On Wed, Jan 21, 2015 at 2:06 PM, Mark Creamer via smartos-discuss <
> smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:
>
>> Probably a simple question - I'd just like to understand the process
>> better before I try it.
>>
>> I have 3 SmartOS hosts running in one subnet. They currently boot from
>> individual USB sticks. I''m interested in moving them to PXE to make new
>> SmartOS releases simpler to implement.
>>
>> Currently there is no DHCP server in that network because none is needed.
>> There are only a few servers and each server has a static IP.
>>
>> Is the network that the PXE boot method uses to boot and load the OS into
>> memory typically the same network as will be used to manage the server?
>>
>> In other words, if my current servers are 192.168.1.100, 101 and 102, and
>> I want to keep those addresses, do I need to change each host to PXE boot
>> from DHCP and use reservations to make sure that each server still gets its
>> original IP address? Or is the PXE boot network independent of the
>> management network and the server just boots from NIC #1 on some other IP
>> but is managed on NIC #2 connected to the "management" network?
>>
>> Hopefully I'm explaining my question well enough. Thanks!
>>
>> --
>> Mark
>> *smartos-discuss* | Archives
>> <https://www.listbox.com/member/archive/184463/=now>;
>> <https://www.listbox.com/member/archive/rss/184463/26900931-98fbc364>; |
>> Modify <https://www.listbox.com/member/?&>; Your Subscription
>> <http://www.listbox.com>;
>>
>
>
>
> --
> Sebastien Perrreault
> Partner
> Les Technologies Alesium Inc

> F: 514-221-3668

item.dc:creator: gtreanto@gmail.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
I just thought I'd follow up as someone in the IRC channel helped me track
down the problem. I had a bad disk in my zpool that was the bottle neck. I
pulled the disk and now I'm getting very good performance over nfs with the
SLOG device.

Thanks for all the help guys!!
I just thought I'd follow up as someone in the IRC channel helped me track
down the problem. I had a bad disk in my zpool that was the bottle neck. I
pulled the disk and now I'm getting very good performance over nfs with the
SLOG device.

Thanks for all the help guys!!
item.dc:creator: greg@leiengineering.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
----- Original Message -----

> From: "Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss" <smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org>
> To: "Robert Mustacchi" <rm@joyent.com>
> Cc: "Peter Toth" <peter.toth198@gmail.com>, "smartos-discuss"
> <smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org>
> Sent: Wednesday, January 21, 2015 3:34:34 PM
> Subject: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM

> I just thought I'd follow up as someone in the IRC channel helped me track
> down the problem. I had a bad disk in my zpool that was the bottle neck. I
> pulled the disk and now I'm getting very good performance over nfs with the
> SLOG device.

> Thanks for all the help guys!!

> smartos-discuss | Archives | Modify Your Subscription

was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was there some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad" disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?

without following this thread, i also added a cheap samsung to a cheap pool expecting to see some amount of improvement but did not. i haven't yet gone back to look any deeper, but this thread makes me want to.

thanks for reporting.
----- Original Message -----

> From: "Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss" <smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org>
> To: "Robert Mustacchi" <rm@joyent.com>
> Cc: "Peter Toth" <peter.toth198@gmail.com>, "smartos-discuss"

> Subject: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM

> I just thought I'd follow up as someone in the IRC channel helped me track

> pulled the disk and now I'm getting very good performance over nfs with the
> SLOG device.

> Thanks for all the help guys!!

> smartos-discuss | Archives | Modify Your Subscription

was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was there some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad" disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?

without following this thread, i also added a cheap samsung to a cheap pool expecting to see some amount of improvement but did not. i haven't yet gone back to look any deeper, but this thread makes me want to.

thanks for reporting.
item.dc:creator: dewey@hyltown.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
>
> was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was there
> some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
> and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad"
> disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?
>


No, it looked fine when I did zpool status. I was just getting horrible
performance in my KVM zone. I added the an intel 3700 and it didn't make
much difference. SIGXCPU from the IRC channel helped me run an i/o test on
all devices in the pool and the bad device was pegged at 100% usage while
the slog and other devices where just idling. I pulled that one device
from the pool and the performance in the KVM VM container shot up and the
iostate of the devices showed pretty equal usage across the pool.

Greg
>
> was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was there
> some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
> and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad"
> disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?
>


No, it looked fine when I did zpool status. I was just getting horrible
performance in my KVM zone. I added the an intel 3700 and it didn't make
much difference. SIGXCPU from the IRC channel helped me run an i/o test on
all devices in the pool and the bad device was pegged at 100% usage while
the slog and other devices where just idling. I pulled that one device
from the pool and the performance in the KVM VM container shot up and the
iostate of the devices showed pretty equal usage across the pool.

Greg
item.dc:creator: greg@leiengineering.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss wrote:
>
> was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was
> there some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
> and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with
> "bad" disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?
>
>
>
> No, it looked fine when I did zpool status. I was just getting
> horrible performance in my KVM zone. I added the an intel 3700 and it
> didn't make much difference. SIGXCPU from the IRC channel helped me
> run an i/o test on all devices in the pool and the bad device was
> pegged at 100% usage while the slog and other devices where just
> idling. I pulled that one device from the pool and the performance in
> the KVM VM container shot up and the iostate of the devices showed
> pretty equal usage across the pool.
>

Which is why I suggested iostat....

"zpool iostat" hides too much information to use as a debugging tool.

--
Ian.

>
> was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] MongoDB Image VS Generic
item.description:
>
> https://docs.joyent.com/images/smartos/mongodb
>
> which details all the specifics about the MongoDB instances. Its some
> tuning and all the pre-reqs installed.
>

It would be nice if that documented whatever the "tuning" was. It doesn't.

Personally, I'd much rather start from a Base64 image and install what I
know I need, so I know exactly how the zone is set up from start to
finish. If there's some special black magic going on, as was implied, it
would be nice to know what that is.

-Tim
>
> https://docs.joyent.com/images/smartos/mongodb
>
> which details all the specifics about the MongoDB instances. Its some
> tuning and all the pre-reqs installed.
>

It would be nice if that documented whatever the "tuning" was. It doesn't.

Personally, I'd much rather start from a Base64 image and install what I
know I need, so I know exactly how the zone is set up from start to
finish. If there's some special black magic going on, as was implied, it
would be nice to know what that is.

-Tim

Nicholas

item.dc:creator: emptysands@gmail.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
On a reasonably up to date ZFS, if you "properly" (not just physically)
remove it, the pool will just deal with it. Have tested this a couple of
days ago.
Make sure your ZFS version supports slog removal.

On Thu, Jan 22, 2015 at 3:32 PM, Nicholas Lee <emptysands@gmail.com> wrote:

>
>
> On 22 January 2015 at 10:54, Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss <
> smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:
>
>> was your disk marked as bad (and the pool marked degraded) or was there
>>> some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
>>> and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad"
>>> disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?
>>>
>>
>>
>> No, it looked fine when I did zpool status. I was just getting horrible
>> performance in my KVM zone. I added the an intel 3700 and it didn't make
>> much difference. SIGXCPU from the IRC channel helped me run an i/o test on
>> all devices in the pool and the bad device was pegged at 100% usage while
>> the slog and other devices where just idling. I pulled that one device
>> from the pool and the performance in the KVM VM container shot up and the
>> iostate of the devices showed pretty equal usage across the pool.
>>
>>
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess it's a
> bit hard to remove the slog now.
>
> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>
>
> Nicholas
>
On a reasonably up to date ZFS, if you "properly" (not just physically)
remove it, the pool will just deal with it. Have tested this a couple of
days ago.
Make sure your ZFS version supports slog removal.

On Thu, Jan 22, 2015 at 3:32 PM, Nicholas Lee <emptysands@gmail.com> wrote:

>
>
> On 22 January 2015 at 10:54, Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss <
> smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:
>

>>> some other way of determining your disk was "bad" ?
>>> and what does your original test look like (was 90-ish MB/s with "bad"
>>> disk plus slog) without the "bad" disk?
>>>
>>
>>
>> No, it looked fine when I did zpool status. I was just getting horrible
>> performance in my KVM zone. I added the an intel 3700 and it didn't make
>> much difference. SIGXCPU from the IRC channel helped me run an i/o test on
>> all devices in the pool and the bad device was pegged at 100% usage while
>> the slog and other devices where just idling. I pulled that one device
>> from the pool and the performance in the KVM VM container shot up and the
>> iostate of the devices showed pretty equal usage across the pool.
>>
>>
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess it's a
> bit hard to remove the slog now.
>
> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>

> Nicholas

item.dc:creator: peter.toth198@gmail.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
Nicholas Lee via smartos-discuss wrote:

>
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess
> it's a bit hard to remove the slog now.
>
> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>

Logs, spares and cache devices can be added and removed without
interrupting pool operation.

--
Ian.
Nicholas Lee via smartos-discuss wrote:

>
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess
> it's a bit hard to remove the slog now.
>
> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>

Logs, spares and cache devices can be added and removed without
interrupting pool operation.

--
Ian.
item.dc:creator: ian@ianshome.com

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Filesystem read/write speed in Centos VM
item.description:
>
> On 22 January 2015 at 10:54, Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss <
> smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess it's a
> bit hard to remove the slog now.
>

No the i/o issues were caused by the lack of a good slog. However, the bad
disk made me initially think the slog wasn't working.

Once I removed the bad disk from the pool, the i/o performance for the KVM
increased quite alot. Now I'm seeing really good speeds in the KVM.


> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>

Yes, the pool will work fine if I remove the slog, but I'm not going to do
that. :)

Greg
>
> On 22 January 2015 at 10:54, Greg Zartman via smartos-discuss <
> smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org> wrote:
> Was this bad disk that root cause of your KVM i/o issues? I guess it's a
> bit hard to remove the slog now.
>

No the i/o issues were caused by the lack of a good slog. However, the bad
disk made me initially think the slog wasn't working.

Once I removed the bad disk from the pool, the i/o performance for the KVM
increased quite alot. Now I'm seeing really good speeds in the KVM.


> Although wont the pool keep operating if you offline it?
>

Yes, the pool will work fine if I remove the slog, but I'm not going to do
that. :)

Greg
item.dc:creator: greg@leiengineering.com

item.title: Etherstub and Vnic Problems
item.description:
Hi SmartOS Community,

I have a problem with using etherstubs and vnics.
I configured it like it was explained in several tutorials and howtos,
but it doesnt work. (No Ping, nothing.(Yea, Firewall on PFsense is
disabled for the Test))

I created an etherstub with "/dladm create-etherstub vswitch0/" with the
following vnics:

/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# dladm show-vnic//
//LINK OVER SPEED MACADDRESS MACADDRTYPE VID ZONE//
//vnic0 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:ed:34:1c random 0 --//
//vnic1 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:26:67:53 random 0 --//
//vnic2 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:9f:76:f2 random 0 --//
//net0 bge0 0 a2:1b:92:58:74:57 fixed 0
00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6//
//net1 vswitch0 0 d2:b1:26:aa:b5:8 fixed 0
00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6//
//net0 vswitch0 0 42:42:67:71:92:d fixed 0
53659df6-03d1-4441-af81-450d120b1a4a//
//net0 vswitch0 0 82:9a:7a:89:84:a1 fixed 0
ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3/

00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6 is a Firewall (PFsense) with
following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/pfsense.json//
//{//
// "alias": "pfsense2",//
// "hostname": "pfsense2",//
// "brand": "kvm",//
// "vcpus": 1,//
// "autoboot": false,//
// "ram": 1024,//
// "disks": [//
// {//
// "boot": true,//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "size": 10240//
// }//
// ],//
// "nics": [//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "admin",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "allow_ip_spoofing": true,//
// "primary":"1"//
// },//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "allow_ip_spoofing": true//
// }//
// ]//
//}//
/
53659df6-03d1-4441-af81-450d120b1a4a is a Centos 6.6 Server with
following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_1.json//
//{//
// "alias": "centos6.6_1",//
// "hostname": "centos6.6_1",//
// "brand": "kvm",//
// "vcpus": 1,//
// "autoboot": false,//
// "ram": 1024,//
// "disks": [//
// {//
// "boot": true,//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "size": 4096//
// }//
// ],//
// "nics": [//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
// "interface": "vnic1",//
// "physical": "vnic1",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "primary": true//
// }//
// ]//
//}/

ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3 is a Centos 6.6 Server with
following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_2.json//
//{//
// "alias": "centos6.6_2",//
// "hostname": "centos6.6_2",//
// "brand": "kvm",//
// "vcpus": 1,//
// "autoboot": false,//
// "ram": 1024,//
// "disks": [//
// {//
// "boot": true,//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "size": 4096//
// }//
// ],//
// "nics": [//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
// "interface": "vnic2",//
// "physical": "vnic2",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "primary": true//
// }//
// ]//
//}/


Hi SmartOS Community,

I have a problem with using etherstubs and vnics.
I configured it like it was explained in several tutorials and howtos,
but it doesnt work. (No Ping, nothing.(Yea, Firewall on PFsense is
disabled for the Test))

I created an etherstub with "/dladm create-etherstub vswitch0/" with the
following vnics:

/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# dladm show-vnic//

//net1 vswitch0 0 d2:b1:26:aa:b5:8 fixed 0
00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6//
//net0 vswitch0 0 42:42:67:71:92:d fixed 0
53659df6-03d1-4441-af81-450d120b1a4a//
//net0 vswitch0 0 82:9a:7a:89:84:a1 fixed 0
ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3/

00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6 is a Firewall (PFsense) with
following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/pfsense.json//

//}//
/

following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_1.json//
//{//
// "alias": "centos6.6_1",//
// "hostname": "centos6.6_1",//
// "brand": "kvm",//
// "vcpus": 1,//
// "autoboot": false,//
// "ram": 1024,//
// "disks": [//
// {//
// "boot": true,//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "size": 4096//
// }//
// ],//
// "nics": [//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
// "interface": "vnic1",//
// "physical": "vnic1",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "primary": true//
// }//
// ]//
//}/

ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3 is a Centos 6.6 Server with
following Config:
/[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_2.json//
//{//
// "alias": "centos6.6_2",//
// "hostname": "centos6.6_2",//
// "brand": "kvm",//
// "vcpus": 1,//
// "autoboot": false,//
// "ram": 1024,//
// "disks": [//
// {//
// "boot": true,//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "size": 4096//
// }//
// ],//
// "nics": [//
// {//
// "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
// "interface": "vnic2",//
// "physical": "vnic2",//
// "model": "virtio",//
// "ip": "dhcp",//
// "primary": true//
// }//
// ]//
//}/
item.dc:creator: lukas.kaltenbach@kesslernetworks.de

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] Etherstub and Vnic Problems
item.description:
Add:

My network config is correct, so the problem must be in the smartos
config. But where?


Kind Regards,
Lukas


Am 22.01.2015 um 09:03 schrieb Lukas Kaltenbach via smartos-discuss:
> Hi SmartOS Community,
>
> I have a problem with using etherstubs and vnics.
> I configured it like it was explained in several tutorials and howtos,
> but it doesnt work. (No Ping, nothing.(Yea, Firewall on PFsense is
> disabled for the Test))
>
> I created an etherstub with "/dladm create-etherstub vswitch0/" with
> the following vnics:
>
> /[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# dladm show-vnic//
> //LINK OVER SPEED MACADDRESS MACADDRTYPE VID ZONE//
> //vnic0 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:ed:34:1c random 0 --//
> //vnic1 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:26:67:53 random 0 --//
> //vnic2 vswitch0 0 2:8:20:9f:76:f2 random 0 --//
> //net0 bge0 0 a2:1b:92:58:74:57 fixed 0
> 00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6//
> //net1 vswitch0 0 d2:b1:26:aa:b5:8 fixed 0
> 00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6//
> //net0 vswitch0 0 42:42:67:71:92:d fixed 0
> 53659df6-03d1-4441-af81-450d120b1a4a//
> //net0 vswitch0 0 82:9a:7a:89:84:a1 fixed 0
> ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3/
>
> 00b969ba-332f-4444-83ab-9e87a16282a6 is a Firewall (PFsense) with
> following Config:
> /[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/pfsense.json//
> //{//
> // "alias": "pfsense2",//
> // "hostname": "pfsense2",//
> // "brand": "kvm",//
> // "vcpus": 1,//
> // "autoboot": false,//
> // "ram": 1024,//
> // "disks": [//
> // {//
> // "boot": true,//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "size": 10240//
> // }//
> // ],//
> // "nics": [//
> // {//
> // "nic_tag": "admin",//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "ip": "dhcp",//
> // "allow_ip_spoofing": true,//
> // "primary":"1"//
> // },//
> // {//
> // "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "ip": "dhcp",//
> // "allow_ip_spoofing": true//
> // }//
> // ]//
> //}//
> /
> 53659df6-03d1-4441-af81-450d120b1a4a is a Centos 6.6 Server with
> following Config:
> /[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_1.json//
> //{//
> // "alias": "centos6.6_1",//
> // "hostname": "centos6.6_1",//
> // "brand": "kvm",//
> // "vcpus": 1,//
> // "autoboot": false,//
> // "ram": 1024,//
> // "disks": [//
> // {//
> // "boot": true,//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "size": 4096//
> // }//
> // ],//
> // "nics": [//
> // {//
> // "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
> // "interface": "vnic1",//
> // "physical": "vnic1",//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "ip": "dhcp",//
> // "primary": true//
> // }//
> // ]//
> //}/
>
> ea1f281b-17d5-45ef-9471-d9442a5471d3 is a Centos 6.6 Server with
> following Config:
> /[root@00-19-99-20-c1-37 ~]# cat /zones/json/centos6.6_2.json//
> //{//
> // "alias": "centos6.6_2",//
> // "hostname": "centos6.6_2",//
> // "brand": "kvm",//
> // "vcpus": 1,//
> // "autoboot": false,//
> // "ram": 1024,//
> // "disks": [//
> // {//
> // "boot": true,//
> // "model": "virtio",//
> // "size": 4096//
> // }//
> // ],//
> // "nics": [//
> // {//
> // "nic_tag": "vswitch0",//
> // "interface": "vnic2",//
> // "physical": "vnic2",//
> // "model": "virtio",//

item.dc:creator: lukas.kaltenbach@kesslernetworks.de

item.title: Re: [smartos-discuss] MongoDB Image VS Generic
item.description:
The templates for those images are on github so you can look into the customize script and the zoneinit part to know what was done:

https://github.com/joyent/mi-mongodb


-- 
Daniel


On 22 January 2015 at 00:36:29, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss (smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org) wrote:

https://docs.joyent.com/images/smartos/mongodb

which details all the specifics about the MongoDB instances. Its some tuning and all the pre-reqs installed.

It would be nice if that documented whatever the "tuning" was.  It doesn't.

Personally, I'd much rather start from a Base64 image and install what I know I need, so I know exactly how the zone is set up from start to finish.  If there's some special black magic going on, as was implied, it would be nice to know what that is.

-Tim

smartos-discuss | Archives | Modify Your Subscription The templates for those images are on github so you can look into the customize script and the zoneinit part to know what was done:

https://github.com/joyent/mi-mongodb


-- 
Daniel


On 22 January 2015 at 00:36:29, Tim Boudreau via smartos-discuss (smartos-discuss@lists.smartos.org) wrote:

https://docs.joyent.com/images/smartos/mongodb

which details all the specifics about the MongoDB instances. Its some tuning and all the pre-reqs installed.

It would be nice if that documented whatever the "tuning" was.  It doesn't.

Personally, I'd much rather start from a Base64 image and install what I know I need, so I know exactly how the zone is set up from start to finish.  If there's some special black magic going on, as was implied, it would be nice to know what that is.

-Tim
